verb.description: Crush (a hard or brittle foodstuff) with the teeth, making a loud but muffled grinding sound.
examples: she paused to crunch a ginger snap

verb.description: Process large amounts of information or perform operations of great complexity, especially by computer.
examples: computers crunch data from real-world observations

noun.description: A loud muffled grinding sound made when crushing, moving over, or hitting something.
examples: Marco's fist struck Brian's nose with a crunch

noun.description: A crucial point or situation, typically one at which a decision with important consequences must be made.
examples: when it comes to the crunch you chicken out

noun.description: A physical exercise designed to strengthen the abdominal muscles; a sit-up.

origin: Early 19th century (as a verb): variant of 17th-century cranch (probably imitative), by association with crush and munch.
